images.caption: Euglenids of the genus Euglena are very active flagellates, orienting themselves using a red light-perceptive spot on the front end of their body. A flagellum and a conspicuous paramylon grain, containing storage substance (paramylon), are also visible in the picture. Photo text: Prof. Aloisie Poulíčková

Euglena may change its body shape – it has a flexible pellicle (case). It moves using a single flagellum. A bright red light-perceptive spot – stigma, a pulsing vacuole and numerous green chloroplasts are visible in the picture. Photo: Prof. Aloisie Poulíčková
Euglenids of the genus Phacus have a rigid pellicle (case), they thus do not change their body shape. Photo: Doc. Petr Hašler
